chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.paragraph: The Time Traveller (for so it will be convenient to speak of him) was expounding a recondite matter to us. His pale grey eyes shone and twinkled, and his usually pale face was flushed and animated with an eager excitement. The fire burnt brightly, and the soft radiance of the incandescent lights in the lilies of silver caught the bubbles that flashed and passed in our glasses.

speaker.person: You must follow me carefully. I shall have to controvert one or two ideas that are almost universally accepted.
Is not that rather a large thing to expect us to begin upon?
The geometry, for instance, they taught you at school is founded on a misconception.

chapter.paragraph: The proposed an invention that could make use of this Theory of the Fourth Dimension, allowing for travel through this fourth dimensionâ€”Time itself.

speaker.person: But how can we move through Time?
Ah, that is where my machine comes in. For time, as we understand it, is only a kind of Space.
